elements.content: The hydrothermal reactions of either uranyl nitrate or uranium trioxide with 4-carboxyphenylphosphonic acid and HF/CsOH in the presence of Cs+ or Ba2+ cations result in the formation of Cs2{(UO2)2(PO3HC6H4CO2H)3(PO3C6H4CO2H)F} (CsUcpp-1), Cs4{(UO2)6(PO3C6H4CO2H)8}(H2O)7 (CsUcpp-2), Ba{(UO2)2(PO3C6H4CO2H)2F2}(H2O)2 (BaUcpp-1), and Cs3{(UO2)(O3PC6H4CO2)}3(H2O)3·4H2O (CsUcpp-3). All these compounds contain the UO2 2+ moiety coordinated by five additional donor atoms resulting in a pentagonal bipyramidal coordination environment. CsUcpp-1, CsUcpp-2, and BaUcpp-1 were isolated at low pH, whereas CsUcpp-3 was synthesized at high pH giving rise to complete elimination of protonation of phosphonic and carboxylic acid moieties. The pH of the reaction is playing a vital role in the formation of the pillared structures in which the carboxylate and phosphonate moieties are coordinated to uranium center in CsUcpp-3, while in the other three compounds, the carboxylate moiety coordinate exclusively to the Cs+ or Ba2+ cations.

elements.content: Four new uranyl carboxyphenylphosphonates, Cs2{(UO2)2(PO3HC6H4CO2H)3(PO3C6H4CO2H)F} (CsUcpp-1), Cs4{(UO2)6(PO3C6H4CO2H)8} (CsUcpp-2), Ba{(UO2)2(PO3C6H4CO2H)2F2}(H2O)2 (BaUcpp-1), and Cs3{(UO2)(O3PC6H4CO2)}3(H2O)3·4H2O (CsUcpp-3), have been prepared to examine differences in the coordination environment around uranium center in the presence of softer metal cations and how pH plays a vital role in the synthesis of three-dimensional framework structure of CsUcpp-3.

elements.content: The solid-state chemistry of actinide arylphosphonates has been underexplored despite their important roles in nuclear waste management and separation processes. To have safe nuclear stewardship, issues like the safety of nuclear power plants, the disposal of nuclear waste, and the diversion of nuclear material from the production of nuclear weapons are being urgently addressed. Until recently, our understanding of the structural chemistry of actinide arylphosphonates have been limited mostly to those of uranyl phenylphosphonate reported by Clearfield et al. and a handful of other compounds. The coordination chemistry of uranium is dominated by U(VI), which is found within the uranyl cation, UO2 2+, that has an effective charge of 3.3 because of its covalent interactions with the two axial oxygen atoms. In addition, they commonly yield low-dimensional layered structures with diverse coordination environments favoring tetragonal, pentagonal, and hexagonal bipyramidal geometries in almost boundless combinations. Series of isolated uranyl phosphonates have demonstrated potential application in ion-exchange, ionic conductivity, intercalation chemistry, photochemistry, nonlinear optical materials, and catalysis.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The solid-state chemistry of actinide arylphosphonates has been underexplored despite their important roles in nuclear waste management and separation processes. To have safe nuclear stewardship, issues like the safety of nuclear power plants, the disposal of nuclear waste, and the diversion of nuclear material from the production of nuclear weapons are being urgently addressed. Until recently, our understanding of the structural chemistry of actinide arylphosphonates have been limited mostly to those of uranyl phenylphosphonate reported by Clearfield et al. and a handful of other compounds. The coordination chemistry of uranium is dominated by U(VI), which is found within the uranyl cation, UO2 2+, that has an effective charge of 3.3 because of its covalent interactions with the two axial oxygen atoms. In addition, they commonly yield low-dimensional layered structures with diverse coordination environments favoring tetragonal, pentagonal, and hexagonal bipyramidal geometries in almost boundless combinations. Series of isolated uranyl phosphonates have demonstrated potential application in ion-exchange, ionic conductivity, intercalation chemistry, photochemistry, nonlinear optical materials, and catalysis.

elements.content: The coordination and migration of actinides have been investigated in high-level spent nuclear waste to understand their behavior in biological and geological environments. These studies revealed that the migratory behavior of actinides are governed by various factors: redox potential, pH, sorption onto mineral surfaces, interaction with organic matters, and bacterial surfaces. There was a speculation that bacteria could be used to remove metals and actinide from aqueous waste streams based on results of the studies that revealed the precipitation of uranyl phosphate on the outside of the bacterial cell. The constituents of bacterial cell wall consist of various reactive groups like lipopolysaccharides, peptidoglycan, or phospholipids and they are able to survive in extremely harsh habitats like uranium waste piles. The interaction of actinides with bacteria are largely influenced by a phosphonate (−PO3) and carboxylate (−CO2) groups that are constituents of the cellular wall of bacteria that consists of multifunctional groups like hydroxyl, amino, phosphoryl, and carboxyl groups. The choice of 4-carboxyphenylphosphonic acid provides a suitable model system for understanding the multifunctionality of bacterial surfaces.

elements.content: We have demonstrated in our previous reports that rigid phenyldiphosphonates can be used to construct pillared uranyl structures in the presence of organic amines as structure directing agents. When we replaced the aromatic amines with the Cs+ cation to template the structure of a uranyl phenyldiphosphonate, Cs3.62H0.38{(UO2)4[C6H4(PO2OH)2]3[C6H4(PO3)2]F2} results. This compound possesses a remarkable elliptical uranyl nanotubular structure, and atypical ion-exchange properties where the cations on the interior of the tubes exchange much more rapidly than those on the exterior. By replacing one of the phosphonate with carboxylate group, a second functionality is introduced into the system resulting in carboxyphenylphosphonates. The comparative studies of phosphonates and carboxylates in solution, and carboxyphosphonates under hydrothermal conditions revealed that the PO3 moiety has a much stronger propensity for binding the U(VI) centers than the CO2 moiety. The compounds are typically layered, when either alkali metal or organoammonium cations are used in the synthesis, the anionic uranyl carboxyphosphonate layers are separated by the cations so that the overall charge balance are maintained. In the carboxyphosphonates systems, there is potential for binding to a second metal center, i.e. transition metals (softer Lewis acid), through the soft Lewis base CO2 – anion, to yield heterobimetallic compounds. Transition metals have been used to connect low-dimensional uranyl phosphonoacetate networks into three-dimensional frameworks, for example, in [H3O](UO2)2Cu2(PPA)3(H2O)2 and (UO2)2(PPA)2(HPPA)Zn2(H2O)2 ·3H2O (PPA = phosphonoacetate). Using 4-carboxyphenylphosphonic acid, we have examined the differences in bonding between Th(IV) and U(VI) and the carboxylate portion of this ligand. As an extension of the previous work on carboxyalkylphosphonates, we have further probed how carboxyphenylphosphonates may sterically influence the coordination and formation of the framework structures by increasing the pH of the reaction. Herein we report the syntheses, structural haracterization, and fluorescence properties of Cs2{(UO2)2(PO3HC6H4CO2H)3(PO3C6H4CO2H)F} (CsUcpp-1), Cs4{(UO2)6(PO3C6H4CO2H)8}(H2O)7 (CsUcpp-2), Ba{(UO2)2(PO3C6H4CO2H)2F2}(H2O)2 (BaUcpp-1), and Cs3{(UO2)(O3PC6H4CO2)}3(H2O)3.4H2O (CsUcpp-3).

elements.content: UO3 (98%, Strem), UO2(NO3)2·6H2O (98%, International Bio-Analytical Industries), barium chloride (99%, Acros Organics), cesium chloride (99%, Alfa Aesar), HF (48 wt %, Aldrich), cesium hydroxide monohydrate (96%, Alfa Aesar), and 4-carboxyphenylphosphonic acid (95%, Epsilon Chimie) were used as received. Reactions were run in PTFE-lined Parr 4749 autoclaves with a 23 mL internal volume. Distilled and Millipore filtered water with resistance of 18.2 MΩ·cm was used in all reactions. Caution! While all the uranium compounds used in these studies contained depleted uranium salts, standard precautions were performed for handling radioactive materials, and all studies were conducted in a laboratory dedicated to studies on actinide elements.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Synthesis

UO3 (98%, Strem), UO2(NO3)2⋅6H2O (98%, International Bio-Analytical Industries), barium chloride (99%, Acros Organics), cesium chloride (99%, Alfa Aesar), HF (48 wt %, Aldrich), cesium hydroxide monohydrate (96%, Alfa Aesar), and 4-carboxyphenylphosphonic acid (95%, Epsilon Chimie) were used as received. Reactions were run in PTFE-lined Parr 4749 autoclaves with a 23 mL internal volume. Distilled and Millipore filtered water with resistance of 18.2 MΩ⋅cm was used in all reactions.  Caution! While all the uranium compounds used in these studies contained depleted uranium salts, standard precautions were performed for handling radioactive materials, and all studies were conducted in a laboratory dedicated to studies on actinide elements.

elements.content: UO2(NO3)2·6H2O (50.6 mg, 0.1 mmol), 4-carboxyphenylphosphonic acid (40.4 mg, 0.2 mmol), CsCl (16.9 mg, 0.1 mmol), 0.7 mL of water, and a very small quantities of HF were loaded into a 23 mL autoclave. The autoclave was sealed and heated to 200 °C in a box furnace for 3 days and was then cooled at an average rate of 5 °C/h to 25 °C. The resulting yellow product was washed with distilled water and methanol and allowed to air-dry at room temperature. Yellow tablets of CsUcpp-1 were isolated as major product and CsUcpp-2 as minor product along with unidentifiable powders. (pH = 2.50). When UO3 (28.6 mg, 0.1 mmol), CsCl (34.0 mg, 0.2 mmol), and H2O (1.0 mL) were substituted in the above reaction in a reduced amount of HF, and heated in a box furnace for 5 days CsUcpp-2 was isolated as a pure phase after cooling at an average rate of 3 °C/h to 25 °C, and confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction (pH = 1.70, yield = 62.6% based on uranium).

After heated for 5 days at 200 °C in a box furnace, it was cooled to 25 °C at an average rate of 3 °C/h. Yellow needles of CsUcpp-3 were isolated along with unidentifiable powder. (pH = 4.66).

After heated for 5 days at 200 °C in a box furnace, it was cooled to 25 °C at an average rate of 3 °C/h. Yellow needles of CsUcpp-3 were isolated along with unidentifiable powder. (pH = 4.66).

elements.content: Single crystals of CsUcpp-1, CsUcpp-2, BaUcpp-1, and CsUcpp-3 were mounted on glass fibers and optically aligned on a Bruker APEXII CCD X-ray diffractometer using a digital camera. Initial intensity measurements were either performed using a standard sealed tube (Mo) with a monocapillary collimator. Standard APEXII software was used for determination of the unit cells and data collection control. The intensities of reflections of a sphere were collected by a combination of four sets of exposures (frames). Each set had a different φ angle for the crystal and each exposure covered a range of 0.5° in ω. A total of 1464 frames were collected with an exposure time per frame of 30 or 40 s, depending on the crystal. SAINT software was used for data integration including Lorentz and polarization corrections. Semiempirical absorption corrections were applied using the program SADABS. The program suite SHELXTL was used for space group determination (XPREP), direct methods structure solution (XS), and least-squares refinement (XL). The final refinements included anisotropic displacement parameters for all atoms. Selected crystallographic information are listed in Table –. Atomic coordinates, bond distances, and additional structural information are provided in the (CIF’s).
elements.clean_text:
Crystallographic Studies

Single crystals of CsUcpp-1, CsUcpp-2, BaUcpp-1, and CsUcpp-3 were mounted on glass fibers and optically aligned on a Bruker APEXII CCD X-ray diffractometer using a digital camera. Initial intensity measurements were either performed using a standard sealed tube (Mo) with a monocapillary collimator. Standard APEXII software was used for determination of the unit cells and data collection control. The intensities of reflections of a sphere were collected by a combination of four sets of exposures (frames). Each set had a different φ angle for the crystal and each exposure covered a range of 0.5° in ω. A total of 1464 frames were collected with an exposure time per frame of 30 or 40 s, depending on the crystal. SAINT software was used for data integration including Lorentz and polarization corrections. Semiempirical absorption corrections were applied using the program SADABS. The program suite SHELXTL was used for space group determination (XPREP), direct methods structure solution (XS), and least-squares refinement (XL). The final refinements included anisotropic displacement parameters for all atoms. Selected crystallographic information are listed in Table    -. Atomic coordinates, bond distances, and additional structural information are provided in the  (CIF's).

Powder X-ray diffraction patterns were collected for CsUcpp-1 and BaUcpp-1 on a Scintag theta–theta diffractometer equipped with a diffracted-beamed monochromatic set for Cu Kα (λ = 1.5418 Å) radiation at room temperature in the angular range from 5° to 65° (2θ) with a scanning step width of 0.05° and a fixed counting time of 1 s/step. The collected patterns were compared with those calculated from single-crystal data using ATOMS and Mercury (see ).
elements.clean_text:
Powder X-ray Diffraction

Powder X-ray diffraction patterns were collected for CsUcpp-1 and BaUcpp-1 on a Scintag theta-theta diffractometer equipped with a diffracted-beamed monochromatic set for Cu Kα (λ = 1.5418 Å) radiation at room temperature in the angular range from 5° to 65° (2θ) with a scanning step width of 0.05° and a fixed counting time of 1 s/step. The collected patterns were compared with those calculated from single-crystal data using ATOMS and Mercury (see ).

elements.content: Fluorescence and absorption data were acquired from the four compounds from single crystals using a Craic Technologies UV–vis-NIR microspectrophotometer with a fluorescence attachment. Excitation was achieved using 365 nm light from a mercury lamp for the fluorescence spectroscopy. The absorption spectra are provided in the .
elements.clean_text:
Fluorescence Spectroscopy

Fluorescence and absorption data were acquired from the four compounds from single crystals using a Craic Technologies UV-vis-NIR microspectrophotometer with a fluorescence attachment. Excitation was achieved using 365 nm light from a mercury lamp for the fluorescence spectroscopy. The absorption spectra are provided in the .

elements.content: CsUcpp-1, CsUcpp-2, BaUcpp-1, and CsUcpp-3 can be prepared under mild hydrothermal conditions. The addition of HF to the reactions is essential, and it serves as both a mineralizing agent and ligand in the preparation of CsUcpp-1 and BaUcpp-1 and only as a mineralizing agent in the synthesis of CsUcpp-2. The amount of HF added must be carefully controlled to avoid isolation of uranium fluorides as the predominant product. HF has substantial effects on the reactions, and substantially affects crystallinity even if it is not incorporated into the final product. Attempts to increase the yield and purity of CsUcpp-3 by adjusting the reaction temperature, increasing the heating duration from 3 to 5 days, and ratios of the reactants did not result in producing a pure product. The influence of increasing the pH of the reaction by adding cesium hydroxide monohydrate is very important in the isolation of three-dimensional structure of CsUcpp-3 in which the protonation of phosphonic and carboxylic acid moieties were completely eliminated.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis

 CsUcpp-1, CsUcpp-2, BaUcpp-1, and CsUcpp-3 can be prepared under mild hydrothermal conditions. The addition of HF to the reactions is essential, and it serves as both a mineralizing agent and ligand in the preparation of CsUcpp-1 and BaUcpp-1 and only as a mineralizing agent in the synthesis of CsUcpp-2. The amount of HF added must be carefully controlled to avoid isolation of uranium fluorides as the predominant product. HF has substantial effects on the reactions, and substantially affects crystallinity even if it is not incorporated into the final product. Attempts to increase the yield and purity of CsUcpp-3 by adjusting the reaction temperature, increasing the heating duration from 3 to 5 days, and ratios of the reactants did not result in producing a pure product. The influence of increasing the pH of the reaction by adding cesium hydroxide monohydrate is very important in the isolation of three-dimensional structure of CsUcpp-3 in which the protonation of phosphonic and carboxylic acid moieties were completely eliminated.

elements.content: CsUcpp-1 consists of a UO6F pentagonal bipyramidal geometry with two independent uranyl groups and four independent carboxyphosphonate ligands. The overall structure as viewed along the a-axis reveals UO6F coordination environment in which the phenyl rings of the carboxyphosphonate moiety are arranged in a trans fashion as shown in Figure . This arrangement is similar to those found in β-uranyl phenylphosphonate except that the orientations of the phenyl rings are pointed in the direction that is up–down–up–down in pattern while in the uranyl carboxyphenylphosphonate structure, the phenylcarboxylates are pointed in up–down–down–up orientations due to the influence of the cesium metal cations that are structure directing (defining “up” orientation as pointing upward away from uranyl layers and “down” orientation as pointing downward from uranyl layers). The uranium units share a single corner via bridging fluoride ions to form uranyl dimers that are connected through the phosphonate oxygen atoms to create uranyl phosphonate chains as depicted in Figure . The carboxylate ends are pointing in-between the chains resulting into layers. Seated in the interlayer are the Cs+ cations that stitched the anionic groups together, so that the overall charged balance is maintained.
elements.clean_text:
Structure of Cs2{(UO2)2(PO3HC6H4CO2H)3(PO3C6H4CO2H)F} (CsUcpp-1)

 CsUcpp-1 consists of a UO6F pentagonal bipyramidal geometry with two independent uranyl groups and four independent carboxyphosphonate ligands. The overall structure as viewed along the a-axis reveals UO6F coordination environment in which the phenyl rings of the carboxyphosphonate moiety are arranged in a trans fashion as shown in Figure . This arrangement is similar to those found in β-uranyl phenylphosphonate except that the orientations of the phenyl rings are pointed in the direction that is up-down-up-down in pattern while in the uranyl carboxyphenylphosphonate structure, the phenylcarboxylates are pointed in up-down-down-up orientations due to the influence of the cesium metal cations that are structure directing (defining "up" orientation as pointing upward away from uranyl layers and "down" orientation as pointing downward from uranyl layers). The uranium units share a single corner via bridging fluoride ions to form uranyl dimers that are connected through the phosphonate oxygen atoms to create uranyl phosphonate chains as depicted in Figure . The carboxylate ends are pointing in-between the chains resulting into layers. Seated in the interlayer are the Cs+ cations that stitched the anionic groups together, so that the overall charged balance is maintained.

elements.content: The uranium coordinates with two oxo atoms at the axial positions resulting in a [OUO]2+ unit, with the average UO bond distances of 1.778(5) and 1.773(5) Å for U(1) and U(2) respectively. The UO6F units are formed from the oxygen atoms from phosphonate moieties along equatorial axis, U–O bonds range from 2.288(5) to 2.397(5) Å. The U–F bonds are within the range, and have U(1)–F(1) bond distance of 2.289(4) Å and U(2)–F(1) bond distance of 2.343(4) Å. The assignments of either F or O atoms were made based on the improvements in the refinements when the correct element was selected. Typically when the element was incorrectly identified, it became nonpositive definite when refined anisotropically. These distances result in bond-valence sums of 6.04 for U(1) and 6.08 For U(2), which are consistent with U(VI). The four independent phosphonates have shorter P–O bond distances that range from 1.488(5) to 1.531(5) Å, and the longer P–O bond distances of 1.555(5), 1.570(5), and 1.579(5) Å reveal the presence of protonated phosphonate groups, and correspond to oxygen atoms that do not coordinate to uranium centers. The C–O bonds within the carboxylate moiety range between 1.205(9) and 1.330(10) Å. The protonation of the C–O group is indicative of the slight asymmetry of the C–O bonds. The shorter C–O bond length represents the oxygen atom interacting with the Cs+ cations. The oxygen atoms involved in the considerably longer C–O bonds are terminal. This is indicative of a C–OH group, and is required for charge balance considerations. The Cs(1) cations form nine long contacts that range from 3.126(6) to 3.573(5) Å with two uranyl oxo atoms, five phosphonate oxygen atoms and two carboxylate oxygen atoms while Cs(2) cation also forms nine long contacts that range from 3.010(7) to 3.799(5) Å with two uranyl oxo atoms, two phosphonate oxygen atoms, four carboxylate oxygen atoms, and a fluoride anion.

elements.content: The structure of CsUcpp-2 is constructed from UO7 pentagonal bipyramidal geometry consisting of six independent uranyl groups and eight independent carboxyphosphonate groups. A view along the [ab] plane reveals a clear view of the edge-sharing uranyl dimers, and the cocrystallized water molecules that interact with the cesium cations. The uranium centers are linked through phosphonate oxygen atoms into uranyl sheets as shown in Figure . These uranyl sheets are stitched together by cesium cations through long contacts, and the carboxylate ends are intertwined as shown in Figure .
elements.clean_text:
Structure of Cs4{(UO2)6(PO3C6H4CO2H)8}(H2O)7 (CsUcpp-2)

The structure of CsUcpp-2 is constructed from UO7 pentagonal bipyramidal geometry consisting of six independent uranyl groups and eight independent carboxyphosphonate groups. A view along the [ab] plane reveals a clear view of the edge-sharing uranyl dimers, and the cocrystallized water molecules that interact with the cesium cations. The uranium centers are linked through phosphonate oxygen atoms into uranyl sheets as shown in Figure . These uranyl sheets are stitched together by cesium cations through long contacts, and the carboxylate ends are intertwined as shown in Figure .

elements.content: The uranium atoms are coordinated by two nearly linear oxo atoms along the axial positions creating a characteristic uranyl cation, UO2 2+, with average UO bond distance of 1.782(8) Å. The additional five oxygen atoms from the phosphonate moiety are bound to the uranyl cation in the equatorial plane with bond distance ranging from 2.237(8) to 2.582(8) Å. The bond-valence sum for the six uranium centers are 6.05, 6.01, 6.09, 6.04, 6.02, and 6.01 for U(1) to U(6), these agree well with the formal oxidation state of +6. The three P–O bond distances range from 1.497(8) to 1.569(8) Å, the longest bond distances reveal the presence of bridging μ2-O atoms. The slight asymmetry of the C–O bonds is indicative of the presence of C–OH groups. The C–O bond distances range from 1.182(16) to 1.347(16) Å. This structure is composed from four hydrated Cs+ cations. Cs(1) cation forms ten long contacts that range from 3.136(8) to 3.788(8) Å with uranyl oxo atom, four phosphonate oxygen atoms, one carboxylate oxygen atom, and four water molecules. Cs(2) cation forms ten long contacts that range from 2.914(10) to 3.656(8) Å with five phosphonate oxygen atoms, one carboxylate oxygen atom, and four water molecules. Cs(3) cation forms six long contacts that range from 3.049(8) to 3.378(9) Å with three uranyl oxo atoms, two carboxylate oxygen atom, and one water molecule. Cs(4) cation forms six long contacts that range from 2.960(9) to 3.36(4) Å with three uranyl oxo atoms, one carboxylate oxygen atom and two water molecules.

elements.content: The structure of BaUcpp-1 contains uranium oxyfluoride groups that are connected through vertices into uranyl chains via the fluoride anions, these UO5F2 pentagonal bipyramids are further connected through the phosphonate oxygen atoms into uranyl phosphonate sheet as shown in Figure . A view along [bc] plane reveals layers of uranyl phosphonates with the carboxylate ends projecting into the interlayer. These layers are stitched together by barium cations, through the carboxylate ends and the uncoordinated phosphonate oxygen atoms similar to the structure of UCscpp-1.
elements.clean_text:
Structure of Ba{(UO2)2(PO3C6H4CO2H)2F2}(H2O)2 (BaUcpp-1)

The structure of BaUcpp-1 contains uranium oxyfluoride groups that are connected through vertices into uranyl chains via the fluoride anions, these UO5F2 pentagonal bipyramids are further connected through the phosphonate oxygen atoms into uranyl phosphonate sheet as shown in Figure . A view along [bc] plane reveals layers of uranyl phosphonates with the carboxylate ends projecting into the interlayer. These layers are stitched together by barium cations, through the carboxylate ends and the uncoordinated phosphonate oxygen atoms similar to the structure of UCscpp-1.

elements.content: The uranium center coordinates with two nearly linear oxo atoms resulting into a classical uranyl, UO2 2+ units, with bond angle of 179.5(4)° and normal UO bond distances of 1.779(9) and 1.784(9) Å. At the equatorial positions, the U–O bonds range from 2.292(8) to 2.343(8) Å while the longer U–F bond distances are 2.348(7) and 2.417(7) Å. These distances result in a bond-valence sum of 5.80, which is consistent with U(VI). The P–O bond distances P(1)–O(4) and P(1)–O(5) are 1.524(9) and 1.524(9) Å, they are bridging μ2-O atoms and are longer than the P(1)O(3) bond of 1.477(9) Å. These bond distances are indicative of complete elimination of protonation of phosphonate moiety and they are involved in coordination to one or both uranium centers and barium cations. The structural feature observed in the C–O bonds within the carboxylate moiety is similar to those discussed in previous two structures. One of the asymmetric C–O bonds coordinates exclusively to barium cations only. The Ba–O contacts are shorter than Cs–O contacts. The hydrated Ba(1) cation forms ten long contacts that range from 2.783(9) to 2.984(9) Å with two each of the carboxylate oxygen atoms, cocrystallized water molecules and fluorine atoms, and four phosphonate oxygen atoms.

elements.content: The structure is strikingly different from the other three carboxyphosphonate compounds reported here. Instead of low-dimensional layered structures, this compound adopts a three-dimensional framework structure with voids along the b axis as shown in Figure . These voids are approximately 6 × 7 x 6 Å, and house cesium ions and disordered water molecules. This three-dimensional framework structure is synthesized through the high-pH synthesis, and differs from the observed layered structures obtained at low-pH in that the carboxylate moiety is completely deprotonated and is coordinated to the uranium center. The orientation of the second uranyl oxo atoms are nearly perpendicular to the U(1) to accommodate this coordination environment as clearly shown in Figure .
elements.clean_text:
Structure of Cs3{(UO2)(O3PC6H4CO2)}3(H2O)3⋅4H2O (CsUcpp-3)

The structure is strikingly different from the other three carboxyphosphonate compounds reported here. Instead of low-dimensional layered structures, this compound adopts a three-dimensional framework structure with voids along the b axis as shown in Figure . These voids are approximately 6 × 7 x 6 Å, and house cesium ions and disordered water molecules. This three-dimensional framework structure is synthesized through the high-pH synthesis, and differs from the observed layered structures obtained at low-pH in that the carboxylate moiety is completely deprotonated and is coordinated to the uranium center. The orientation of the second uranyl oxo atoms are nearly perpendicular to the U(1) to accommodate this coordination environment as clearly shown in Figure .

elements.content: The structure consists of two uranyl centers, U(1) and U(2), that are found as UO7 pentagonal bipyramids. The uranium atoms are coordinated by two nearly linear oxo atoms, UO2 2+ cations, and the OUO bond angles are 179.0(3)° and 177.9(5)° with normal average UO bond distances of 1.801(8) Å and 1.786(10) Å for U(1) and U(2), respectively. The U–O bond distances from phosphonates are shorter than the U–O bond distances from carboxylates. U(1) is coordinated by three phosphonate oxygen atoms with bond distances that range from 2.286(7) to 2.297(7) Å, while the other two equatorial sites are to the two oxygen atoms from carboxylate moiety with bond distances of 2.461(7) and 2.503(7) Å. For U(2), three of the equatorial oxygen atoms are from phosphonate groups with bond distances that range from 2.268(7) to 2.303(10) Å, and the remaining two atoms are from carboxylate moiety with symmetric bond distances 2.492(8) Å ( ×2). The bond-valence sums for U(1) and U(2) are 6.00 and 6.12 respectively, they are both consistent with the formal oxidation state of U(VI). There are two cesium ion sites. Cs(1) forms eight long bonds that range from 3.218(11) to 3.428(7) Å with uranyl oxo atoms and axial oxygen atoms as well as oxygen atoms from phosphonate and carboxylate moieties. While Cs(2) forms seven long bonds that range from 3.024(18) to 3.552(8) Å by interacting with uranyl oxo atoms, oxygen atoms from phosphonate, carboxylate groups and the cocrystallized water molecules.

elements.content: Some interesting observations can be drawn from the way the phosphonate and carboxylate groups are coordinated around the uranium center in these four uranyl carboxyphosphonate structures. The low-pH syntheses (pH < 3.0) yield structures in which all the carboxylates and some phosphonates are protonated. Based on this feature, the phosphonate moiety coordinates preferentially but not exclusively to uranium whereas the carboxylate moiety binds exclusively to the cesium or barium metal ions in CsUcpp-1, CsUcpp-2, and BaUcpp-1. The patterns of coordination in the first two cesium compounds differ from the barium compound. In CsUcpp-1 and CsUcpp-2, the phosphonates bind either uranium or cesium and coordinate less often to both centers with μ2-O atoms. In BaUcpp-1, the phosphonate coordinate to either uranium or both uranium and barium metal centers with μ2-O atoms. This result is different from the previously reported observations in which the carboxylate moieties of the carboxyphenylphosphonate bind the uranium centers while the phosphonate portions of the ligand primarily coordinate the U(VI) centers. The high-pH synthesis (pH > 4) yields CsUcpp-3, a three-dimensional framework structure in which protonation is completely eliminated in all the phosphonate and carboxylate moieties. This result agrees with previously reported observation in which addition of CsOH to phosphonoacetate led to isolation of Cs[(UO2)(PO3CH2CO2)], in which three of the equatorial U–O bonds are from phosphonate moiety and the remaining two from carboxylate moiety. There are asymmetric C–O bond distances in CsUcpp-1, CsUcpp-2, and BaUcpp-1 structures, the shorter C–O bond lengths represent the oxygen atoms forming long contacts with metal cations. The oxygen atoms involved in the considerable longer C–O bonds do not interact with metal cations. This is indicative of a protonated C–O groups. The symmetric C–O bonds found in CsUcpp-3 reveals the complete elimination of protonation in the C–O group (see Tables ). Unlike in Na[UO2(PO3CH2CO2)]·H2O and Cs[UO2(PO3CH2CO2)] structure where Na+/Cs+ are only playing the role of space filling and not directly involved in the formation of the structure, the Cs+ and Ba2+ cations in these structures are mediating the formation of these compounds by the influence of their charges (+1/+2) as clearly shown in Figures and , respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Comments on the Coordination Environments of Uranyl Carboxyphosphonates

Some interesting observations can be drawn from the way the phosphonate and carboxylate groups are coordinated around the uranium center in these four uranyl carboxyphosphonate structures. The low-pH syntheses (pH < 3.0) yield structures in which all the carboxylates and some phosphonates are protonated. Based on this feature, the phosphonate moiety coordinates preferentially but not exclusively to uranium whereas the carboxylate moiety binds exclusively to the cesium or barium metal ions in CsUcpp-1, CsUcpp-2, and BaUcpp-1. The patterns of coordination in the first two cesium compounds differ from the barium compound. In CsUcpp-1 and CsUcpp-2, the phosphonates bind either uranium or cesium and coordinate less often to both centers with μ2-O atoms. In BaUcpp-1, the phosphonate coordinate to either uranium or both uranium and barium metal centers with μ2-O atoms. This result is different from the previously reported observations in which the carboxylate moieties of the carboxyphenylphosphonate bind the uranium centers while the phosphonate portions of the ligand primarily coordinate the U(VI) centers. The high-pH synthesis (pH > 4) yields CsUcpp-3, a three-dimensional framework structure in which protonation is completely eliminated in all the phosphonate and carboxylate moieties. This result agrees with previously reported observation in which addition of CsOH to phosphonoacetate led to isolation of Cs[(UO2)(PO3CH2CO2)], in which three of the equatorial U-O bonds are from phosphonate moiety and the remaining two from carboxylate moiety. There are asymmetric C-O bond distances in CsUcpp-1, CsUcpp-2, and BaUcpp-1 structures, the shorter C-O bond lengths represent the oxygen atoms forming long contacts with metal cations. The oxygen atoms involved in the considerable longer C-O bonds do not interact with metal cations. This is indicative of a protonated C-O groups. The symmetric C-O bonds found in CsUcpp-3 reveals the complete elimination of protonation in the C-O group (see Tables ). Unlike in Na[UO2(PO3CH2CO2)]⋅H2O and Cs[UO2(PO3CH2CO2)] structure where Na+/Cs+ are only playing the role of space filling and not directly involved in the formation of the structure, the Cs+ and Ba2+ cations in these structures are mediating the formation of these compounds by the influence of their charges (+1/+2) as clearly shown in Figures  and , respectively.

elements.content: The diagram of uranium(VI) phosphate polyhedra in these four compounds are depicted in Figure . The structure of CsUcpp-1 reveals the chain of uranyl phosphate polyhedra resembling those found in A6[(UO2)2O(MoO4)4] (A = Na, K and Rb) while the chain of uranyl phosphate polyhedral in CsUcpp-3 resembles [(UO2)(CrO4)(H2O) x ] y (H2O) z (where x = y=z = 1, x = 2 y = 4 z = 9 and x = 2 y = 1 z = 0). The UO5F2 chains in BaUcpp-1 are linked into sheets of uranyl polyhedra by phosphate anions resembling the structure of [(NH4)2(UO2)(SO4)2(H2O)](H2O).

elements.content: The emission of green light centered near 520 nm by compounds containing uranyl cations has been known for centuries. This emission can be strong enough that the natural long-wavelength UV light in sunlight is enough to make some compounds glow green, and can be seen clearly with the naked eye. The charge-transfer based emission is in fact vibronically coupled to both bending and stretching modes of the uranyl cation, and typically consists of five-peak spectrum, although far more lines can be observed at low temperature. Various factors like crystallinity of the sample, disorder within the equatorial plane of the uranyl group, etc. are responsible for the decrease in resolution of individual transitions. Denning and co-workers have examined in detail these transitions for the solid samples containing the [UO2Cl4]2– anion owing to its crystallization in a cubic space group. However, not all uranyl compounds fluoresce and the mechanisms of the emission from uranyl containing compounds is complex. Grohol and Clearfield demonstrated a considerable variance in the luminescence properties of two closely related uranyl phenylphosphonate compounds, [UO2(HO3PC6H5)2(H2O)]2·8H2O and UO2(HO3PC6H5)2(H2O)·2H2O, whose structural differences are based on the conformational differences of the phosphonate anions. As shown in Figure , all these four uranyl carboxyphenylphosphonate compounds are luminescent. Five peaks are clearly resolved for these compounds with peak bands ranging from 488 to 611 nm, that correspond to electronic and vibronic transitions S11–S00 and S10–S0v (v = 0–4). As for the benchmark compound, UO2(NO3)2·6H2O, the most intense peak (S10–S00) is positioned at 509 nm and the peak bands range from 487 to 612 nm. The major difference in the spectra of these four compounds was the resolution of the peaks, which was due to varied crystal sizes and qualities. CsUcpp-1 exhibits a slight red shift along with lesser intensity for the emission bands followed by BaUcpp-1, CsUcpp-2 and CsUcpp-3 compared to the benchmark compound. This slight difference may be attributed to the coordination environment around uranium center, UO6F and UO7, and the coordination effect of the carboxyphenylphosphonate ligand.
elements.clean_text:
Fluorescence Spectroscopy

The emission of green light centered near 520 nm by compounds containing uranyl cations has been known for centuries. This emission can be strong enough that the natural long-wavelength UV light in sunlight is enough to make some compounds glow green, and can be seen clearly with the naked eye. The charge-transfer based emission is in fact vibronically coupled to both bending and stretching modes of the uranyl cation, and typically consists of five-peak spectrum, although far more lines can be observed at low temperature. Various factors like crystallinity of the sample, disorder within the equatorial plane of the uranyl group, etc. are responsible for the decrease in resolution of individual transitions. Denning and co-workers have examined in detail these transitions for the solid samples containing the [UO2Cl4]2- anion owing to its crystallization in a cubic space group. However, not all uranyl compounds fluoresce and the mechanisms of the emission from uranyl containing compounds is complex. Grohol and Clearfield demonstrated a considerable variance in the luminescence properties of two closely related uranyl phenylphosphonate compounds, [UO2(HO3PC6H5)2(H2O)]2⋅8H2O and UO2(HO3PC6H5)2(H2O)⋅2H2O, whose structural differences are based on the conformational differences of the phosphonate anions. As shown in Figure , all these four uranyl carboxyphenylphosphonate compounds are luminescent. Five peaks are clearly resolved for these compounds with peak bands ranging from 488 to 611 nm, that correspond to electronic and vibronic transitions S11-S00 and S10-S0v  (v = 0-4). As for the benchmark compound, UO2(NO3)2⋅6H2O, the most intense peak (S10-S00) is positioned at 509 nm and the peak bands range from 487 to 612 nm. The major difference in the spectra of these four compounds was the resolution of the peaks, which was due to varied crystal sizes and qualities. CsUcpp-1 exhibits a slight red shift along with lesser intensity for the emission bands followed by BaUcpp-1, CsUcpp-2 and CsUcpp-3 compared to the benchmark compound. This slight difference may be attributed to the coordination environment around uranium center, UO6F and UO7, and the coordination effect of the carboxyphenylphosphonate ligand.

elements.content: The purpose of this work was to compare the coordination chemistry of uranium compounds that contain the carboxyalkylphosphonate and carboxyphenylphosphonate ligands. The structural disparity between these materials is largely attributed to the steric influence from the organic residues. The use of the phenyl spacer tends to acts as pillaring agent linking the adjacent layers. In carboxyalkylphosphonate, at low pH, the carboxylate moiety preferentially binds the softer metal cations, that is, Cu2+, Zn2+, and alkali metal cations; whereas in carboxyphenylphosphonate, the carboxylate moiety exclusively binds the softer metal cations and only coordinate to uranium centers when protonation is completely eliminated. We have shown the influence of the pH in the syntheses of uranyl carboxyphenylphosphonates. The layered structures are linked into three-dimensional framework by adjusting the pH of the reaction. The pH is playing more important role in these syntheses along with the charges on the metal cation and steric influence of the phenyl ring. However, the central issue we intend to address in the ongoing studies is to incorporate 3d and 4f metals cations in order to probe further the structural variation and electronic properties.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

The purpose of this work was to compare the coordination chemistry of uranium compounds that contain the carboxyalkylphosphonate and carboxyphenylphosphonate ligands. The structural disparity between these materials is largely attributed to the steric influence from the organic residues. The use of the phenyl spacer tends to acts as pillaring agent linking the adjacent layers. In carboxyalkylphosphonate, at low pH, the carboxylate moiety preferentially binds the softer metal cations, that is, Cu2+, Zn2+, and alkali metal cations; whereas in carboxyphenylphosphonate, the carboxylate moiety exclusively binds the softer metal cations and only coordinate to uranium centers when protonation is completely eliminated. We have shown the influence of the pH in the syntheses of uranyl carboxyphenylphosphonates. The layered structures are linked into three-dimensional framework by adjusting the pH of the reaction. The pH is playing more important role in these syntheses along with the charges on the metal cation and steric influence of the phenyl ring. However, the central issue we intend to address in the ongoing studies is to incorporate 3d and 4f metals cations in order to probe further the structural variation and electronic properties.

UO2(NO3)2·6H2O (50.6 mg, 0.1 mmol), 4-carboxyphenylphosphonic acid (40.4 mg, 0.2 mmol), CsCl (16.9 mg, 0.1 mmol), 0.7 mL of water, and a very small quantities of HF were loaded into a 23 mL autoclave. The autoclave was sealed and heated to 200 °C in a box furnace for 3 days and was then cooled at an average rate of 5 °C/h to 25 °C. The resulting yellow product was washed with distilled water and methanol and allowed to air-dry at room temperature. Yellow tablets of CsUcpp-1 were isolated as major product and CsUcpp-2 as minor product along with unidentifiable powders. (pH = 2.50). When UO3 (28.6 mg, 0.1 mmol), CsCl (34.0 mg, 0.2 mmol), and H2O (1.0 mL) were substituted in the above reaction in a reduced amount of HF, and heated in a box furnace for 5 days CsUcpp-2 was isolated as a pure phase after cooling at an average rate of 3 °C/h to 25 °C, and confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction (pH = 1.70, yield = 62.6% based on uranium).

The autoclave was sealed and heated to 200 PoPC in a box furnace for 3 days and was then cooled at an average rate of 5 °C/h to 25 °C. The resulting yellow product was washed with distilled water and methanol and allowed to air-dry at room temperature. Yellow tablets of pure BaUcpp-1 suitable for X-ray studies were isolated and confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction. (pH = 2.36, yield =74.6% based on uranium).

Cs<sub>3</sub>{(UO<sub>2</sub>)(O<sub>3</sub>PC<sub>6</sub>H<sub>4</sub>CO<sub>2</sub>)}<sub>3</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>3</sub>.4H<sub>2</sub>O <bold>CsUcpp-3</bold>

After heated for 5 days at 200 °C in a box furnace, it was cooled to 25 °C at an average rate of 3 °C/h. Yellow needles of CsUcpp-3 were isolated along with unidentifiable powder. (pH = 4.66).

cln_elements.content: Illustration of the layers in Cs2{(UO2)2(PO3HC6H4CO2H)3(PO3C6H4CO2H)F}. The structure is constructed from UO6F pentagonal bipyramids = green, cesium = blue, oxygen = red, phosphorus = magenta, carbon = black, phenyl ring = gray.
cln_elements.clean_text: 1  Illustration of the layers in Cs2{(UO2)2(PO3HC6H4CO2H)3(PO3C6H4CO2H)F}. The structure is constructed from UO6F pentagonal bipyramids = green, cesium = blue, oxygen = red, phosphorus = magenta, carbon = black, phenyl ring = gray.

cln_elements.content: View along the c axis of the Cs2{(UO2)2(PO3HC6H4CO2H)3(PO3C6H4CO2H)F} layers showing cesium ions in the interlayer. UO6F pentagonal bipyramids = green, cesium = blue, oxygen = red, phosphorus = magenta, carbon = black, phenyl ring = gray.
cln_elements.clean_text: 2  View along the c axis of the Cs2{(UO2)2(PO3HC6H4CO2H)3(PO3C6H4CO2H)F} layers showing cesium ions in the interlayer. UO6F pentagonal bipyramids = green, cesium = blue, oxygen = red, phosphorus = magenta, carbon = black, phenyl ring = gray.

cln_elements.content: Polyhedral view along the c axis of Cs4{(UO2)6(PO3C6H4CO2H)8}(H2O)7 showing edge-shared uranyl polyhedral. The structure is constructed from UO7 pentagonal bipyramids = green, cesium = blue, oxygen = red, phosphorus = magenta, carbon = black, phenyl ring = gray.
cln_elements.clean_text: 3  Polyhedral view along the c axis of Cs4{(UO2)6(PO3C6H4CO2H)8}(H2O)7 showing edge-shared uranyl polyhedral. The structure is constructed from UO7 pentagonal bipyramids = green, cesium = blue, oxygen = red, phosphorus = magenta, carbon = black, phenyl ring = gray.

cln_elements.content: Depiction of the stacking of layers in Cs4{(UO2)6(PO3C6H4CO2H)8}(H2O)7 showing the interweaved phenylcarboxylate rings. UO7 pentagonal bipyramids = green, cesium = blue, oxygen = red, phosphorus = magenta, carbon = black, phenyl ring = gray.
cln_elements.clean_text: 4  Depiction of the stacking of layers in Cs4{(UO2)6(PO3C6H4CO2H)8}(H2O)7 showing the interweaved phenylcarboxylate rings. UO7 pentagonal bipyramids = green, cesium = blue, oxygen = red, phosphorus = magenta, carbon = black, phenyl ring = gray.

cln_elements.content: Illustration of [(UO2)2(PO3C6H4CO2H)2F2]2- sheets along the [ab] plane. The uranyl chains are connected through the vertices via fluorine atoms. UO6F pentagonal bipyramids = green, barium = brown, oxygen = red, phosphorus = magenta, carbon = black, phenyl ring = gray.
cln_elements.clean_text: 5  Illustration of [(UO2)2(PO3C6H4CO2H)2F2]2- sheets along the [ab] plane. The uranyl chains are connected through the vertices via fluorine atoms. UO6F pentagonal bipyramids = green, barium = brown, oxygen = red, phosphorus = magenta, carbon = black, phenyl ring = gray.

cln_elements.content: Depiction of the layers in Ba{(UO2)2(PO3C6H4CO2H)2F2}(H2O)2 showing the barium ions and cocrystallized water molecules. The structure is constructed from UO6F pentagonal bipyramids = green, barium = brown, oxygen = red, phosphorus = magenta, carbon = black, phenyl ring = gray.
cln_elements.clean_text: 6  Depiction of the layers in Ba{(UO2)2(PO3C6H4CO2H)2F2}(H2O)2 showing the barium ions and cocrystallized water molecules. The structure is constructed from UO6F pentagonal bipyramids = green, barium = brown, oxygen = red, phosphorus = magenta, carbon = black, phenyl ring = gray.

cln_elements.content: Drawing of three-dimensional framework structure of Cs3{(UO2)(O3PC6H4CO2)}3(H2O)3·4H2O with voids that housed the Cs+ cation and disordered water molecules. The structure is constructed from UO7 pentagonal bipyramids = green, cesium = blue, oxygen = red, phosphorus = magenta, carbon = black, phenyl ring = gray.
cln_elements.clean_text: 7  Drawing of three-dimensional framework structure of Cs3{(UO2)(O3PC6H4CO2)}3(H2O)3⋅4H2O with voids that housed the Cs+ cation and disordered water molecules. cln_elements.content: Depiction of the pillared three-dimensional framework structure of Cs3{(UO2)(O3PC6H4CO2)}3(H2O)3·4H2O showing coordination of carboxylate and phosphonate moieties to uranyl centers. The structure is constructed from UO7 pentagonal bipyramids = green, cesium = blue, oxygen = red, phosphorus = magenta, carbon = black, phenyl ring = gray.
cln_elements.clean_text: 8  Depiction of the pillared three-dimensional framework structure of Cs3{(UO2)(O3PC6H4CO2)}3(H2O)3⋅4H2O showing coordination of carboxylate and phosphonate moieties to uranyl centers. The structure is constructed from UO7 pentagonal bipyramids = green, cesium = blue, oxygen = red, phosphorus = magenta, carbon = black, phenyl ring = gray.

cln_elements.content: Views of the uranyl-phosphate polyhedral of CsUcpp-1, 2, 3, and BaUcpp-1 constructed from UO6F or UO7 pentagonal bipyramids = green, cesium = blue, barium = brown, oxygen = red, phosphate = magenta, fluorine = yellow.
cln_elements.clean_text: 9  Views of the uranyl-phosphate polyhedral of CsUcpp-1, 2, 3, and BaUcpp-1 constructed from UO6F or UO7 pentagonal bipyramids = green, cesium = blue, barium = brown, oxygen = red, phosphate = magenta, fluorine = yellow.

cln_elements.content: Fluorescence spectrum of CsUcpp-1, 2, 3, BaUcpp-1 and UO2(NO3)2·6H2O showing the emission of green light with five well-defined charge-transfer vibronic transitions.
